Friulian[edit]

Alternative forms[edit]

  • Vierte

Etymology[edit]

From the feminine of viert, past participle of vierzi (“to open”). Compare Venetian verta.

Noun[edit]

vierte f

  1. opening
  2. spring (season)

Synonyms[edit]

  • (spring): primevere

German[edit]

German ordinal numbers
 <  3.4.5.  > 
    Cardinal : vier
    Ordinal : vierte

Etymology[edit]

From Old High German fiordo (akin to Old Saxon fiortho), from Proto-Germanic *fedurþô. Compare Dutch vierde, Danish fjerde, English fourth.

Alternative forms[edit]

  • 4te (inflected forms: 4tem, 4ten, 4ter, 4tes)
  • 4. (also stands for inflected forms like vierter, viertes)

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈfiːɐ̯tə/, /ˈfɪʁtə/
  • audio
    		(file)

Ordinal number[edit]

vierte

  1. fourth

Declension[edit]

A user suggests that this German entry be cleaned up, giving the reason: "It's "er ist Vierter" not "er ist vierter", compare findable "er wurde Vierter", "er war Vierter", "Leverkusen [...] ist Vierter in der Tabelle", "Mainz ist Vierter mit [...]".

erste and ordinals after 4th might need the same cleanup as this entry...".

Please see the discussion on Requests for cleanup(+) for more information and remove this template after the problem has been dealt with.

  • 103: tausendste, eintausendste
  • 106: millionste, einmillionste
  • 109: milliardste, einmilliardste
  • 1012: billionste

  • 1018: trillionste
  • 1021: trilliardste
  • 1024: quadrillionste

Spanish[edit]

Verb[edit]

vierte

  1. Informal second-person singular (tú) affirmative imperative form of verter.
  2. Formal second-person singular (usted) present indicative form of verter.
  3. Third-person singular (él, ella, also used with usted?) present indicative form of verter.
